title: Eye Anatomy and Vision Loss
content: The eye is built like a camera where in the very front is the cornea, the covering on the front of a watch; that’s the thing that a contact lens would sit on. The next thing is the pupil, which is the hole in the iris. Behind that is the lens, it’s really one of a couple of different lenses inside the eye; but the lens behind the pupil. Then there is the vitreous cavity and in the very back. The retina, which attaches to the optic nerve, and that’s what goes to the brain. Images come in; they’re bent by the cornea first, then bent again by the lens, and then they focus (hopefully) on the retina. In a perfectly sized eye, in someone who doesn’t need spectacles to see, images come from say, optical infinity, which is for the purposes of this discussion, is about 20 feet or beyond where light rays come in parallel, and they’re bent so that they fall perfectly on the retina.

title: Eye Health and Surgery
content: Eye health is also discussed. What are the things that one can do? What can be done to maximize eye health in our kids? Also discussed are some of the real epidemics that are going on in myopia. That is to say, kids that are requiring glasses earlier and earlier. What could be the cause of this and what can be done in our kids to prevent those things, and also in ourselves, what we can be doing. A lot of stuff is covered in this episode.

title: Eye Surgery Procedures
content: LASIK eye surgery will be explained as well as a procedure that came along slightly before that’s called PRK. Steven will talk a little bit about a procedure that is coming online today, called SMILE. All three of these surgeries are similar, but they differ in fundamental ways, and that can be an important thing to consider for someone in the market for one of these procedures.

title: Ophthalmology Training
content: There are nonsurgical ophthalmologists, but I think they all start out as surgeons to become an ophthalmologist. You’re really training to become an eye surgeon. But there are, for example, neuro-ophthalmologists, which are really more neurologists than eye surgeons; they don’t do eye surgery. There are some ophthalmologists who don’t do eye surgery. The surgical movements are these little tiny movements, so very small positional changes can have a huge impact on the outcome of the surgery.

title: Nearsightedness and Farsightedness
content: Nearsightedness, or myopia, is when images come into focus in a point that is not exactly on the retina, causing problems with distance vision. Farsightedness, or hyperopia, is when near vision is worse than far vision, which might also be blurry. Presbyopia is a condition where the focusing ability is compromised, typically through age, and the person can't see up close.

title: Aging and Vision
content: With age, the elasticity of the lens of the eye decreases, making it harder to focus on near objects. This process continues as the lens becomes less elastic and harder, eventually resulting in a cataract where the lens begins to lose its optical clarity. Cataract formation is considered a universal component of aging, but certain factors can cause premature cataract formation, such as electrocution, head trauma, diabetes, and steroid use.

title: The Lens of the Eye and Blood Sugar
content: The lens of the eye is not a vascular structure. It can allow molecules to diffuse in and out. For example, glucose can diffuse into the lens and cause it to swell, changing its shape and affecting vision. This process can occur over a period of several weeks. If blood sugar levels increase, there may be a lag of a month or two before vision changes, and it takes weeks for vision to return to normal when blood sugar levels decrease.

title: Blood-Retinal Barrier and Systemic Infection
content: The eye is prone to damage from systemic infection. There is a blood-retinal barrier that protects the highly metabolically active retina from systemic disease. The lens itself is relatively privileged from an immune standpoint.

title: Eye Drops in Development
content: Eye drops are being developed that can potentially improve vision by restoring elasticity to the lens. One medication being examined is a lipoic acid choline ester, which is intended to soften the lens and break some of the disulfide bonds that cause loss of elasticity. This medication is in the early experimental phase and must be applied topically.

title: Anatomy of the Eye
content: The pupil of the eye changes size to dilate and constrict. When the pupils are dilated, the iris moves out of the way, allowing the doctor to see into the back of the eye. Pharmacological manipulation of the pupil can improve vision by increasing depth of focus.

title: Presbyopia and Light
content: Presbyopia, or farsightedness, can be worse in darkness. Light makes a difference because it causes the pupil to constrict, improving vision. Reducing the size of the aperture lets in less light, but the light that is let in is in perfect focus, improving vision.

title: Eye Color and UV Protection
content: Darker eye color provides greater protection from UV light. This is similar to how darker skin tones offer more protection from UV light. The retina is one of the most metabolically active tissues in the body and is prone to free radical formation due to constant bombardment with radiation. The pigmented layer behind the retina shields the vascular supply from this radiation.

title: Understanding the Eye's Photoreceptors
content: Cones are primarily for daytime vision and they’re clustered in the center of ones visual sphere, specifically near the center of the macula, which is the central portion of the retina. The rods are in the periphery and they typically are responsible more for dim illumination vision like night vision. They are highly specialized cells referred to as photoreceptors and they have stacks of structures within them that are photosensitive; and that causes a depolarization. Once a photon hits a particular cell photoreceptor, there’s a change in the membrane and ions flow; and that’s how a signal is generated. This ion flow ultimately makes its way to the optic nerve and then to the brain.

title: Visual Processing in the Brain
content: Most of the visual processing is in the very back of the brain. About half of the overall brain structure deals with vision in some capacity. That’s why, for example, when people have a stroke, there’s almost always some component of visual involvement. Pupil responses are controlled by the midbrain, autonomic stuff. Visual processing and the actual mapping of the visual sphere has been mapped to the cortex. Parts of the brain that are specific to edge detection or moving edge detection has been mapped quite elegantly to the cortex.

title: Understanding Human Vision through an Evolutionary Lens
content: Vision is our most highly developed sense. Humans can see so many, many orders of magnitude of change of illuminations. It’s astonishing that our eyes can function in both of those environments. It’s a sense that people value very highly. And also evolutionarily it’s valued highly just owing to the fact that so much of the brain is devoted to vision.

title: Vision Loss due to Trauma
content: Vision loss due to trauma can often be prevented. Injuries are one of the main causes of devastating visual loss in young people. In general, almost all of the big causes and movers of visual loss are senescence-related or age-related. But in young people, it’s trauma. Blunt trauma is the most common eye injury. The eye is pretty well protected with the brow and the cheek, but there are certain things that can get in there and can directly impact the eye. In a young person, trauma is something one has to watch out for.

title: Enhancing Vision beyond 20/20
content: 20/20 simply means that one can see at 20 feet what a “normal” person can see at 20 feet. If one’s vision is 20/10, they can see at 20 feet what a normal person has to get 10 feet up to in order to see. So 20/10 is better than 20/20. There are ways to boost human performance beyond 20/20. The theoretical limit of how well one can see is defined by essentially the pixelation of their retina. This varies from person to person, but it’s somewhere in the vicinity of about 20/08 or so. With a sharp enough image, one could theoretically see better than 20/10. And the only way one can really achieve that is to remove some of the optical irregularities that everyone is born with and somehow neutralize them along with the glasses prescription. Currently, this can be achieved laser vision correction.

title: Laser Vision Correction Compared to Contact Lenses
content: Anyone who’s ever worn contact lenses knows that when they put in a brand new pair, they can see pretty well with them. But then the eye begins to regard that contact lens as a foreign object. So one’s body just begins to attack it, coat it with all sorts of immunological debris. One is susceptible to pollen, dust, whatever it is that coats this formerly pristine object. And let’s say there is correction for astigmatism in that contact lens, where its orientation is important. Every time one blinks, that contact lens moves a little bit. All of those factors contribute to optical performance that is less than what could be achieved with spectacles or laser vision correction.

title: Astigmatism: Definition, Cause, and High Prevalence
content: Astigmatism is when the eye is shaped like a football instead of a basketball. Specifically the cornea, the very front part of the eye, typically. There can be astigmatism in the lens itself, the lens behind the pupil. This simply means the eye is not perfectly shaped; it’s a bit oblong like an egg or football. That means that the power differs by meridian; so one needs a different glasses prescription in this meridian versus this meridian.

title: Prevalence and Evolution of Vision Problems
content: Around 60% of patients with a glasses prescription have some significant degree of astigmatism. The length of the eye is really what determines whether one is nearsighted or farsighted. This is the distance from front to back, anterior-posterior length of the eyeball. Primarily, that is the main driver as to whether one is nearsighted or farsighted. Sometimes it’s the curvature of the cornea that contributes to whether someone is nearsighted or farsighted.

title: Nearsightedness (Myopia): Causes, Epidemic in Children, and Prevention Strategies
content: Nearsightedness can happen over a period of months. If a young person exclusively performs near tasks, their eye will grow longer so that those near objects are in perfect focus. This is what is happening in our current society; children looking at screens, near objects, for hours on end and not going outside often develop nearsightedness. There are two drivers of nearsightedness in the plastic developing human: 1) Deprivation from outdoor light 2) Near work. The risk of nearsightedness can be cut in half by going outside. The light is really the most important driver of protection from nearsightedness. So if one is outside on a bright sunny day, they’re releasing a fair bit of dopamine from the retina and dopamine inhibits the growth of the eye. So the worst thing to do is stay inside in a dimly lit room and perform near tasks. That raises the risk of nearsightedness 16 fold compared to kids who go outside.

title: Genetic Susceptibility to Vision Loss
content: There is a genetic component to vision loss. For siblings of individuals who wear spectacles, there is a higher incidence of myopia or hyperopia. This could be susceptibility. It is not known whether parents of reading children were reading children themselves; so it’s hard to separate out the genetic component; there does seem to be a genetic component as well. But the environmental component seems to be way stronger and more powerful.

title: Impact of Near Tasks on Vision
content: Near tasks such as reading and extended screen time can result in nearsightedness. Things are very well in focus at a typical normal reading distance for someone who has spent a lot of time reading or doing near tasks. This is a result of their development.

title: Cataracts: Impact of Aging and How They Can Be Repaired
content: Cataract formation seems to be fairly inevitable to our species. It’s something that has no bearing on reproductive capacity, but is otherwise inevitable to our species. Most patients in their 70s typically have some cataract formation. Now there are patients who are 80 that are still functioning with cataracts, but the optical clarity of their lenses has degraded to the point that it’s not the way it was when they were 20.

title: Vision Loss Due to Light Exposure and Trauma
content: In the lens, it’s mostly that the lens proteins are degrading or becoming damaged over time. Maybe UV light contributes to this. It’s known that light exposure is related to cataract formation, as are some of the other things previously discussed like: glucose going into the lens, corticosteroid use. It is not known what it is specifically about trauma that causes a premature loss of clarity of the lens proteins.

title: Cataract Surgery
content: Cataract surgery today is like a four or five-minute procedure, and it’s astonishingly effective. Cataract surgery typically is not repeated; it’s a once in a lifetime deal. Now the implant lenses that are put in to replace the cataract, they have advanced in terms of function to the point that they can fix the near vision, as well as the distance vision, the astigmatism, the nearsightedness, the farsightedness, the presbyopia. These are all correctable with artificial lenses that are put in the eye to replace the cataract.

title: Evolution of Intraocular Lenses
content: Intraocular lenses (IOL) have evolved significantly over time. Initially, these lenses were simply designed to replace the cloudy lens with something that provided good distance vision, but the patient would still need to wear spectacles after the surgery. The implant lens is a bendable plastic object; it can be folded up and put through a tiny incision then opened up again. This folding and opening of the implant lens was a significant advancement that happened in the 1980’s.

title: Cataract Treatment in Ancient Times
content: In the ancient world, cataracts were treated by poking the lens of the eye backward, allowing it to drop down into the bottom of the eye so that the person now had a clear optical pathway. This took someone who was functionally blind and allowed them to see shapes. They no longer have a lens, so there is no way to focus. But it’s basically like taking someone who has no light transmission and saying, “We’re going to let unfocused light go through.”

title: The First Implant Lens
content: The first implant lens was developed after World War II by an ophthalmologist in the UK named Harold Ridley. He noticed that some of the RAF fighters would have fragments of their plexiglass canopy inside their eyeballs. He learned very early on that these fragments were biologically inert. The eye was perfectly happy and people could walk around the rest of their lives with a shard of sharp plexiglass inside their eyeball. This led to the idea of using plexiglass (which is essentially polymethyl methacrylate) in the eye, and the body doesn’t really care that it’s there, doesn’t mount an immune response.

title: Current Technology Used in Cataract Surgery
content: Current technology used in cataract surgery involves removing the cataract through a tiny incision. They break it up; essentially they emulsify it with ultrasound. Now sometimes they use a femtosecond laser to break up parts of it. The implant lens can be folded up and put them through that same tiny incision and then they can open up and be exactly where they need to be. A big incision takes longer to heal and induces astigmatism. It’s best for the incision to be tiny.

title: Cataract Surgery Outcomes
content: Cataract surgery can greatly improve the ability to see. Especially now that the implant lenses can correct the near vision and the distance vision. This in addition to the added clarity from just removing the cataract, patients typically have this benefit of not needing spectacles. The number 1 risk of this surgery is infection. It’s extraordinarily unusual; less than 1 in 10,000 cases results in a serious infection.

title: Lens Implants that Can Correct and Improve Vision
content: Not everybody gets the same lens; lens to correct vision are expensive and the patient has to pay some extra money to get them. Regular cataract surgery makes no attempt to get rid of spectacles. Regular cataract surgery is probably going to be completely covered by a person’s health insurance. One may have to pay thousands of dollars out of pocket if they wanted to get rid of their glasses.

title: What Gets Measured at the Clinic?
content: One of the first things that he has to do is make sure that the surface of the cornea is tuned up from a dry eye standpoint. Because dry eye patients, the surface of their corneas, it’s not optically pristine; it’s a little distorted. Contact lens make this a lot worse; it can throw off his measurements. This can throw off the calculation because it’s pretty simple Newtonian physics. Knowing the length of the eyeball, the curvature of the front of the eye, the index of refraction of stuff inside the eyeball (how bendy the material is), and considering where the implant lens is going to reside— a calculation can correct for placing the image on the retina.

title: Implant Technology in Development
content: In the mid-2000s, Steven started getting involved in product design for a type of implant lens that could actually zoom focus front to back. Not a bifocal or a trifocal where there are different zones of focus. But a lens that could actually move or change its shape.

title: Lens Implants and Eye Trauma
content: An implant that was put in humans in multiple clinical trials outside the United States found that these could zoom focus kind of like the human lens would. But multifocal lenses, the bifocals, trifocal implants, they surpassed the capability of what could be achieved with the lenses that were designed. If there was a lens that could change its shape or change its position and zoom focus seamlessly from near to far, that would be a game-changer. When there is trauma to the lens, if you violate that capsule of the lens, the lens immediately becomes cloudy. A shard of rock or glass or something goes through the cornea and embeds itself in the lens. Once that capsule has been pierced, inevitably, lens protein starts leaking out, and it’s no longer an immune privileged site. A cataract becomes visible within days. Now they need a new lens.

title: Corneal Trauma and Dry Eye
content: When there is trauma to the cornea, one doesn’t want a patient’s eyelids flipping open in the middle of surgery when nobody’s paying attention, and the drape is running over the eye and scraping the cornea. An eye that’s been left open in surgery while a patient is asleep and not blinking, that’s the extreme version of dry eye where the cornea has completely dried out. Even if the cornea is not abraded, those epithelial cells would be so damaged by exposure, just by not being continuously bathed in tears that they would be severely damaged. So dry eye is intimately related to corneal abrasion because these patients lack the lubrication that normally takes place to prevent that type of thing.

title: Causes, Treatment, and Prevention of Dry Eye
content: Dry eye is an enormous issue in our society. Lots of medications do it through anticholinergic side effects. Antihistamines, hormonal influences are profound in terms of dry eye. Anything that causes dry mouth can also cause dry eye. Autoimmune conditions can cause dry eyes or Sjogren’s rheumatoid arthritis. All of the connective tissue diseases have a dry eye component to them. Perturbations of thyroid metabolism cause dry eye. A lot of women suffer from dry eye mostly due to a lack of testosterone, that is probably most intimately linked to dry eye.

title: Eye Drops and Omega-3 Fatty Acids for Dry Eye
content: Eye drops work pretty well for most people; most artificial tears come in the form of an eye drop. There are some mist sprays, believe it or not, one is a hypochlorous acid compound that is sprayed on the lids; and it sort of migrates into the eye. This actually is very good for reducing the bacterial counts at the lid margin, which is part of that inflammation cycle that is so critical in dry eye. There’s a very significant benefit from supplementing with omega-3 fatty acids, especially high doses of omega-3 fatty acids and certain types of omega-6 fatty acids such as GLA (gamma-linolenic acid); that’s what you’d find in black current seed oil, borage oil, or evening primrose oil.

title: Sunglasses for Eye Protection
content: There’s a dose-related phenomenon here— too much light is bad; too little light is bad. The most common site of skin cancer is the lower lid. There are lots of basal cell and squamous cell carcinomas, and sunglasses certainly reduce the incidents of that. Consider photoaging of the lens itself; It’s not a bad thing to delay the onset of cataract. Retina macular degeneration; there’s pretty clear evidence that UV exposure, particularly of the magnitude that one can get outside, is associated with an elevated risk of age-related macular degeneration. If the goal is longevity or the postponement of senescence, certainly ocular senescence, it makes sense to protect one’s eyes from UV light.

title: Polarized Sunglasses and UV Protection
content: A polarized lens is a lens that has a bunch of lines drawn in it, all in the same direction, so that some of the light is blocked. Polarized lenses have some pluses and minuses. One of the big minuses is the difficulty in viewing a lot of the displays in cars now. In terms of polarization, there’s no evidence that polarization versus non-polarization in sunglasses helps. It’s really the UV filter that is helpful in terms of protection of eye health. One could wear clear spectacles, as long as they had UV protection, and still achieve the benefit of sunglasses. It’s not the tint that protects the eyes; it’s the ultraviolet protection. The same is true for car windows.

title: Correcting Nearsightedness
content: When a nearsighted person comes in, they can correct this with glasses or contacts. The safest thing you can do is wear spectacles for sure. They’re going to work every time and there’s essentially no risk associated with them. There’s a big debate about what the next safest thing is. Is it contact lens wear for 10 years, where one might be susceptible to infection, or is it laser vision correction? If you’re doing fine with spectacles or contact lenses, do that.

title: Laser Eye Surgery - Photorefractive Keratectomy (PRK)
content: PRK (photorefractive keratectomy), which came alone first. The approvals for PRK and LASIK were in the mid ’90s, 1995, 1996. The first procedure was PRK. The way this came about was an engineer at IBM realizes that excimer lasers, used to etch microchips, could also be used to change the curvature or make cuts in human tissue. And because of the nature of this ultraviolet laser, there was essentially no bystander trauma to the adjacent tissue, so the tissue could be etched or cut. Further, because it generated no heat, there was typically no immune response generated, so these incisions would heal without scarring.

title: How PRK Works
content: The length of the eye cannot be changed; what can be changed is the curvature of the front of the eye. The curvature doesn’t have to change that much; think about how thin a contact lens is. Only a little curvature needs to change in order to focus the light on the retina. PRK does this with an excimer laser on the very front part of the cornea. The very front coating of the cornea is called the epithelium. He removes that layer of cells with a solution of alcohol eye drops; it just sloughs right off, and it grows back in the same configuration. Then he uses a very carefully calibrated laser to change the shape of the cornea.

title: PRK Recovery
content: With PRK the epithelium is removed so now there is a 7-8 mm diameter area of the central cornea that has no epithelium. It has to grow back. That’s like having a big corneal abrasion. Luckily there are drops that can reduce the feeling of the foreign body sensation dramatically. They put a contact lens over the eye; it acts like a band-aid. Then the epithelium begins to heal from the outside in. This takes about 4 days.

title: Laser Eye Surgery - LASIK
content: LASIK is different from PRK because the epithelium is not shaved off; instead a flap is cut. The new shape of the cornea is determined by how much tissue is removed when the flap comes back. The same laser is used in LASIK and PRK. Instead of using the laser on the surface of the eye, a step is added before that.

title: LASIK and PRK Eye Surgery
content: A flap in the cornea is created using a femtosecond laser, allowing work under the epithelium. About 20% of the cornea is taken up. In PRK, the first 10 pages of the cornea are removed. In LASIK, the cornea is opened to page 100 and pages 100-110 are taken out. The body doesn’t perceive that anything has been done in LASIK, and patients typically have 20/20 vision the next morning. LASIK was developed after PRK to get around the healing process of PRK. About 80-85% of the corrective eye surgery in the US today is LASIK.

title: Recovery from LASIK
content: The risk of infection with LASIK is lower because the epithelium is not taken away. However, if the flap is not performed correctly, it can lead to problems. There is more dry eye following LASIK compared to PRK. This is because creating the flap temporarily severs some of the nerves that send the signal from the front of the eye to the lacrimal gland, which secretes tears. These nerves typically regrow back and one reestablishes that feedback mechanism. Some patients have dry eye for really long periods of time after both procedures. The majority of patients are back to their baseline in about 60 to 90 days.

title: Night Vision after Corrective Laser Eye Surgery
content: In the early days of LASIK and PRK, the weakest part of vision was night vision. This was due to the shape of the treatment that was used; and the diameter that was treated was limited. They couldn’t really treat the peripheral part of the cornea that comes into play when the pupils gets big. From the ’90s to now, the treatment beam patterns have changed to address that issue and to treat that peripheral cornea differently. So now, night vision complaints are pretty unusual with laser vision correction.

title: Cost of Laser Corrective Eye Surgery
content: There is no difference in the cost of LASIK and PRK. The added step of LASIK adds some cost. But PRK has more postoperative care; this requires more visits. The cost has stayed pretty stable over the last 20 years; it’s a couple thousand dollars per eye.

title: Contraindications for LASIK and/or PRK
content: There are conditions of the cornea where the cornea is biomechanically unstable, where the cornea actually has a tendency to bow forward in a pathological state. There are patients who have irregularities in their astigmatism that cannot be measured or corrected with any laser vision correction. There are patients that have certain autoimmune diseases that maybe render them as poor candidates for laser vision correction. People who have other eye diseases like cataract, or maybe glaucoma, or retinal pathology are not good candidates for laser vision correction. These operations are typically performed on healthy eyes.

title: When is PRK the Best Option?
content: There are certain patients where PRK is a far better option. Sometimes the thickness of the cornea will dictate this. Sometimes it might be related to someone with preexisting dry eye. There used to be some restrictions in branches of the military. These pretty much all went away; all aviators and pilots can now have LASIK or PRK.

title: Laser Eye Surgery—Small Incision Lenticule Extraction (SMILE)
content: SMILE (small incision lenticule extraction) is an interesting procedure. It’s using a single laser, a femtosecond laser. This is performed through a very small keyhole procedure. This was designed to solve dry eye. The problem it really solved, especially outside the United States, was needing only 1 laser instead of 2. SMILE technology is evolving.

title: Glaucoma: Definition, Causes, Symptoms, and Care
content: Glaucoma is probably about a hundred different diseases, but they all share the final common pathway of damage to the optic nerve (the nerve in the back of the eyes) and the cranial nerve, that is somehow related to pressure. Symptoms of glaucoma include damage to the peripheral vision at the end of glaucoma. Most people will not detect a slight reduction in their peripheral vision, particularly if it’s segmental. But as glaucoma progresses, it can affect central vision, and then it becomes symptomatic. Luckily glaucoma has become much more treatable. The pharmacological management of glaucoma has gotten way better. And there are numerous laser procedures that can treat glaucoma, what are referred to as minimally invasive glaucoma surgery (MIGS).

title: Cause of Glaucoma
content: 80% of glaucoma cases are caused by what is referred to as garden variety chronic open angle glaucoma. This means that the glaucoma is not a function of the anatomy of the front of the eye being too crowded, where the fluid can’t get out. It’s more a problem of overproduction of fluid inside the eye, and the pressure is too high inside the eye. It is not know what causes this; the pathogenesis is likely multifactorial. It runs in families, so there is a family history component but it’s not simple heredity. It is not coupled with diabetes. There’s some relationship to hypertension, blood pressure; but it can be seen in patients who are not hypertensive at all. It’s very common.

title: Tips for Preserving Eye Health
content: Everyone should be screened for glaucoma when they go to the eye doctor for a yearly exam. The appearance of the optic nerve is examined as well as the pressure, and those are probably the two most important things to look for with glaucoma. Incidence does go up with age; so in the 50’s and beyond, it’s much more important to pay attention to glaucoma.

title: Delaying the Onset of Age-Related Diseases
content: An aggressive strategy to mitigate diseases such as cancer, Alzheimer’s disease, etc. is important. Attention should also be given to maintaining the health of teeth, ears, and eyes. It is undesirable to reach old age and have no teeth, be deaf, or be blind.

title: Importance of Eye Protection
content: Hats and sunglasses are effective ways to protect the eyes. However, they are not enough as a certain amount of light bounces off and hits the bottom of one’s cheek and goes right into the eye.

title: Supplements and Eye Health
content: Nutritional supplements might have some effect on eye health. Vitamin C deficiency is associated with an elevated risk of cataract. However, vitamin C supplementation to super normal levels does not protect against cataract formation. Other antioxidants that have been looked at (vitamins A, C, and E) basically have no effect on cataract formation. There is a little bit of mixed weak evidence for lutein and zeaxanthin as possibly being protective for cataract and macular degeneration.

title: Screen Time and Eye Health
content: The amount of UV radiation coming off of screens is sufficiently low that there has been no evidence at all that it’s going to cause macular degeneration. However, blue light can mess up one’s circadian rhythm. Exposure to blue light from a screen at night is not damaging their retinas or giving them cataracts, but may be messing up their circadian rhythms.

title: Contact Lenses: Good Hygiene and Considerations
content: The importance of sunglasses, artificial tears, taking one’s contact lenses out as frequently as possible is emphasized. Don’t sleep in contact lenses. The daily ones seem best if one can afford it. It makes more sense than the 2-week ones that have to be washed every night. The most important thing is to just get them out of the eye.

title: Corrective Eye Surgery
content: The other question Peter had on laser surgery is, how stable does one’s prescription need to be? There are 3 variables to think about: The cornea, The length of the eye, The lens itself. The lens will continue to change throughout life, but typically not until one’s in their 50’s, 50’s, and 70’s, when cataract formation will start to affect the light bending power of the lens. The cornea should not be changing. So just the length of the eye needs to be fixed.

title: Eye Exam as a Window into Metabolic Illness
content: The eye is the most sensitive end organ to excessive glycosylated hemoglobin. It’s also one of the few things one can look at directly. An angio of the eyes can be done noninvasively. Diabetes manifests primarily as a microvascular disease in so many end organs and in the eye, one can actually directly visualize this microvascular disease occurring. If it’s in the eye, it’s probably in the kidney, it’s probably in the toes.

title: A1C Level Monitoring
content: For this individual, that level of A1C is not acceptable. They’ve been very receptive because they know we can directly visualize this.

title: Integration of Ophthalmology into Medicine
content: Ophthalmology should be more integrated into medicine. What ophthalmologists do in some ways operates outside of what the surgeons, and the internists, and endocrinologists do. An ophthalmologist can see something important to systemic health. There should be more of an integration of this.

title: Ophthalmologists' Unique Perspective
content: Ophthalmologists get to directly look at the brain. They can look directly at the central nervous system in a way that a gastroenterologist can directly look at the colon.

title: Effectiveness of Colon Cancer Screening
content: Colon cancer screening is so effective; the doctor gets to look with the naked eye directly at a polyp as it becomes cancerous.

title: Observation of Brain and Vascular Tree
content: It is amazing that we have the ability to directly observe the brain and the vascular tree, and so that’s very, very helpful.
